text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Hi, I'm Dianna, and you're
watching "Physics Girl."

So I grew up in Hawaii
on the island of Kauai,

which is the oldest
of the main islands--

the wettest, the greenest,
the most beautiful.
It had no nightlife.

There were 22 kids in
my graduating class.
I digress.

So the Hawaiian islands
are geologically weird.

They're formed by
volcanoes-- we know that.
But wait, scrap that.
They're formed by volcano--
just one.

It's like an upside-down
chocolate kiss conveyor belt.

There's a hot spot
that forms the volcano.

And then the plates
move over the top,
making the islands one by one.
Bloop, bloop, bloop.
Now you know.

So one of my childhood
friends, Noah Randolph-Flagg,

became a geologist
at UC Berkeley.

And when we were back
home over the holidays,

we went for a hike
and got talking

about how unusual the formation
of the Hawaiian Islands is.
It all started with a mystery.
NOAH: World War II--

the US military was looking
for Japanese submarines
in the Pacific.

And the way they
did that is they'd

lower a magnet off
the side of the boat,

and the magnet would
get pulled down

if there was a metal
submarine under there.

DIANNA (VOICEOVER): The
military mostly used

planes with these
magnetic contraptions,

but scientists later adapted
the technology for boats.

And presumably, they
saw some submarines--

I don't know about that--
but what they also saw was

the magnet would go up and
down sort of periodically
on the ocean floor.

Sometimes it would
pull really hard,

and sometimes it
wouldn't pull very hard.
Do you have a thought on why?
This was the mystery.

This magnetic contraption
was made in wartime

to search for
submarines underwater,

but something else
was pulling on it--

something unidentified
and deep underwater.

I'm going to guess that it had
to do with how much magma was

close to the surface
of the ground,

and, because there's more iron,
I'm guessing, in that rock,
then it pulled harder.
You're totally right.
It's about--
DIANNA: Yes!
Woo!
NOAH: Well, you're totally--
You're not totally right.

DIANNA (VOICEOVER):
Noah's brother,

Jeremy, who's also a
geologist, just told me
that I'm not totally right.

You're totally right that
it's about the iron in the rock.

If you imagine a
molten rock as being

a bunch of little
magnets floating around,

what direction do you think
those magnets would align?

DIANNA: I would imagine
that they would align along
the magnetic field line.
NOAH: Excellent.

OK, so we have all of these
magnets in the molten rock

that align with the
Earth's magnetic field.

And then they freeze,
and they're stuck there.
DIANNA: Oh, OK!
Go on.

NOAH: And the Earth's
magnetic field would reverse.

And so what they were
seeing was these stripes--

was the reversals of the
Earth's magnetic field.
DIANNA: What?
NOAH: Yeah.
DIANNA: What?
Yeah.

And the other thing they
noticed is, across the Pacific,
it's symmetrical.

It looks almost like
a bar code, but it's
a symmetrical bar code.

And they're like, well, that
means that all of that crust

is being produced
in the same place.

And this is how we learned
that the Earth even has plates.

It's the number one thing
you learn in Earth Science.
Tectonic plates.

And we figured it
out because these lines

of little magnets aligned
with Earth's magnetic field

as it flipped over
millions of years

and then was frozen
into the rock.
Amazing!

The vast majority of
volcanic activity on Earth
occurs along plate lines.

And that makes sense
because if you're

going to spill your
guts, you're more
likely to do it along a seam.

But there's one
glaring exception.

NOAH: Hawaii is dead in
the middle of a plate.

Plate tectonics doesn't
explain a place like Hawaii.
So that's sort of a problem.

So what people call
on is this theory
called mantle plume theory.

And the idea is it's
a thermal convection,

as hot stuff is less dense,
cold stuff is more dense.

Cold stuff goes down,
hot stuff comes up.

So you imagine convection as the
boiling of water on your stove
top, right?

In the Earth, that convection
is happening in solid rock.

So we're talking about
motion of solid rock

because at those time
scales and at those length
scales, the ground--
the solid rock that you feel--

is as viscous as the maple
syrup that you're pouring.
DIANNA: That's amazing.

So this is rock
moving through rock.
Yeah.
DIANNA: Wow.

So if you scale things the way
that we think that they scale,
it looks like a lava lamp.

You have some hot stuff rising,
and it starts with a big blob.

And then there's this long,
skinny tail behind it.

The same physics happens
in nuclear bombs--
you know, the mushroom cloud?
It's the same idea.

There's that big buoyant
plume and then the tail--
the skinny tail-- behind.

So the idea is that Hawaii
and the Hawaiian Islands

and these other hot-spot
volcanoes are that tail.
Hold on.

So this mantle plume theory
says that an unusual hot spot

like Hawaii is just the
tail end of that blob

shape of solid rock
rising through solid rock.
That's it.

So then you might ask,
well, where's the big--
DIANNA: Where's the bubble?
Where's the bubble?

People have argued is that those
bubbles are these things called
flood basalts.
This is good, I promise.

This huge bubble just
explodes onto the surface.

And so most of Siberia
is covered in lava flows.

And most of India is
covered in lava flows.

Individual lava flows that
are hundreds and hundreds

of feet tall that cover
an entire country.
DIANNA: Wow so that was, like--

The thought is
that was the bubble.
DIANNA: The bubble exploding?

Yeah, that's that bubble
exploding into the surface.
This is the tail and the head.

DIANNA: And then as the
head gets higher and higher,
the pressure is released.

And that means
that the solid rock

is going to start turning
from a solid into a liquid.
Yeah.

And so that's what
we call magma.
And the reason it's super--

DIANNA: So have we ever seen
anything like that happen?
Never.
Never.

DIANNA: Would it be an
incredibly violent event?
Well, this gets good.
DIANNA: [LAUGHS]

There have been many
extinctions in Earth history.

And many of them
correspond with when

we think these bubbles
explode to the surface.

So the most recent one
was 40 million years ago,

and it was tiny,
like a thousandth
of the size of some of these.

But the largest extinction
in Earth history--

the Permian-Triassic-- happens
during the largest flood
basalt.

So yeah, let's hope that
doesn't happen anytime soon.

OK, so recap-- the
Hawaiian Islands

are forming on a hot spot
that's the result of one

of these mantle
plumes popping up

through the crust
like a hot pimple.
You're welcome.

And this might tell us something
about the geology on the planet
Mars.

We think that plate tectonics
is not happening on Mars.

But we think that,
probably, mantle plumes are,

and that's why we have these
giant volcanoes, like Olympus
Mons.

And part of why
Olympus Mons is so big

is because there's
not plate tectonics.

So stuff's sort of piling
up in the same place.

But in Hawaii, because the plate
is moving, you get snapshots.

It's exactly like how
your video camera works

as you're taking a
series of stills,

and you can see the
progression through time.

And so what we see
in the Hawaiian chain

is a series of stills of
the island through time.

So when you go to the Big
Island, that's it being born.

And then you can trace
that chain of islands

to here, which is
5 million years.

And you can trace
it all the way--
To Japan.
--all the way up to Siberia.
DIANNA: Really?
Yeah.
You go--

DIANNA: That is the line
of the motion of plates
over that one--
NOAH: Yes.
Do me a favor.

Go to Google Maps
or Google Earth

and pull up the
Hawaiian Islands--

maybe after you finish
watching this video.

Turn on satellite
view, and you'll

see a line of old mountains
traced by the same hot spot
all the way up to Siberia.
It's incredible.

And you'll notice
the line is crooked,

which means that, at some
point, the plate just changed

direction, which is weird,
but crazy that you can tell

something like
this about history
from looking at the ocean floor.

So you can take the distance
between the Hawaiian Islands--
we actually know the ages--

and you can
calculate a velocity.

And those are the
same velocities
that we measure with GPSs now.
DIANNA: That's so cool.
NOAH: Yeah, that's really cool.

So there's a lot of
stuff we're still learning
about the Hawaiian Islands.

Thanks to Noah for
trying to quench
my unquenchable curiosity.
Thanks to you for watching.

Subscribe if you
want more physics

or whatever we decide
to get physical with.
And--
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Just kidding.
Happy physics-ing.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
That was awesome.
OK.
